verses.text: Then Job answered and said ,
I know \add it is\add* so of a truth : but how should man be just with God ?\f + \fr 9.2 \ft with God: or, before God?\f*
If he will contend with him, he cannot answer him one of a thousand.
\add He is\add* wise in heart , and mighty in strength : who hath hardened \add himself\add* against him, and hath prospered ?
Which removeth the mountains , and they know not: which overturneth them in his anger.
Which shaketh the earth out of her place , and the pillars thereof tremble.
Which commandeth the sun , and it riseth not; and sealeth up the stars.
Which alone spreadeth out the heavens , and treadeth upon the waves of the sea.\f + \fr 9.8 \ft waves: Heb. heights\f*
Which maketh Arcturus , Orion , and Pleiades , and the chambers of the south.\f + \fr 9.9 \ft Arcturus…: Heb. Ash, Cesil, and Cimah\f*
Which doeth great things past finding out ; yea, and wonders without number.
Lo, he goeth by me, and I see \add him\add* not: he passeth on also, but I perceive him not.
Behold, he taketh away , who can hinder him? who will say unto him, What doest thou?\f + \fr 9.12 \ft hinder…: Heb. turn him away?\f*
\add If\add* God will not withdraw his anger , the proud helpers do stoop under him.\f + \fr 9.13 \ft proud…: Heb. helpers of pride, or, strength\f* \p
How much less shall I answer him, \add and\add* choose out my words \add to reason\add* with him?
Whom, though I were righteous , \add yet\add* would I not answer , \add but\add* I would make supplication to my judge.
If I had called , and he had answered me; \add yet\add* would I not believe that he had hearkened unto my voice.
For he breaketh me with a tempest , and multiplieth my wounds without cause.
He will not suffer me to take my breath , but filleth me with bitterness.
If \add I speak\add* of strength , lo, \add he is\add* strong : and if of judgment , who shall set me a time \add to plead\add*?
If I justify myself, mine own mouth shall condemn me: \add if I say\add*, I \add am\add* perfect , it shall also prove me perverse.
\add Though\add* I \add were\add* perfect , \add yet\add* would I not know my soul : I would despise my life. \p
This \add is\add* one \add thing\add*, therefore I said \add it\add*, He destroyeth the perfect and the wicked.
If the scourge slay suddenly , he will laugh at the trial of the innocent.
The earth is given into the hand of the wicked : he covereth the faces of the judges thereof; if not, where , \add and\add* who \add is\add* he? \p
Now my days are swifter than a post : they flee away , they see no good.
They are passed away as the swift ships : as the eagle \add that\add* hasteth to the prey.\f + \fr 9.26 \ft swift…: or, ships of Ebeh: Heb. ships of desire\f*
If I say , I will forget my complaint , I will leave off my heaviness , and comfort \add myself:\add*
I am afraid of all my sorrows , I know that thou wilt not hold me innocent.
\add If\add* I be wicked , why then labour I in vain ?
If I wash myself with snow water , and make my hands never so clean ;
Yet shalt thou plunge me in the ditch , and mine own clothes shall abhor me.\f + \fr 9.31 \ft abhor…: or, make me to be abhorred\f*
For \add he is\add* not a man , as I \add am, that\add* I should answer him, \add and\add* we should come together in judgment.
Neither is there any daysman betwixt us, \add that\add* might lay his hand upon us both.\f + \fr 9.33 \ft any…: Heb. one that should argue\f*\f + \fr 9.33 \ft daysman: or, umpire\f*
Let him take his rod away from me, and let not his fear terrify me:
\add Then\add* would I speak , and not fear him; but \add it is\add* not so with me.\f + \fr 9.35 \ft it is…: Heb. I am not so with myself\f*
